description: Direct Salisbury Township Right-to-Know (RTK) / Open Records request form. This is the most useful because it is the township's own form, tailored for requesting local records (planning/zoning), and will be processed directly by the township records officer. Use this to specify historical zoning ordinances, date ranges, file formats, and any known ordinance numbers for fastest handling.

Pennsylvania Office of Open Records (state) online RTK request form. A good alternative if you prefer a state-hosted portal or need guidance; it lists municipalities (including Salisbury Township) and links to the standard downloadable RTK forms. Useful if you want to ensure correct RTK procedure or escalate a denial, but less direct than submitting the township's own form.

Direct NextRequest public records portal for submitting new records requests. Easy online submission, includes guidance and links for police-specific requests and public records policy — best for requesting historical zoning ordinances and archives.

Embedded Box document repository that lets you search/access already-published public records (useful for finding posted historical ordinances). Includes a link to submit a public records request but is less direct for creating new requests than the NextRequest portal.

Direct NextRequest submission page — the easiest and most useful for filing a public records request immediately. Lets you create a new, trackable request and often provides instructions/fields tailored to municipal records, making it ideal for requesting historical zoning ordinances.

NextRequest portal home — very useful as an alternative because it lets you search existing requests and links to the Laserfiche public portal for agendas, minutes, ordinances, and resolutions (which may already contain historical zoning ordinances). Good if you want to find records first or access archives without submitting a new request.

City's general Public Records Request page — provides the official request form and links (including Community Development/Planning), but is less direct than the NextRequest portal for submission, tracking, and searching responsive documents/archives.

Direct JustFOIA public records request portal for City of Redmond, Oregon (Administration). Best option — built for submitting general records requests (including planning/zoning and historical ordinances), straightforward to use, and targets the correct jurisdiction (Redmond, OR).

City of Redmond public records information page (appears to be Redmond, WA). Useful as a general model or for links/instructions, but likely the wrong jurisdiction for Redmond, OR records — less directly useful for obtaining Redmond, OR historical zoning ordinances.

Online public records request portal for City of Redmond, Washington. Functional for submitting records requests in Redmond, WA but not applicable to Redmond, OR — therefore the least useful resource for requesting Redmond, OR historical zoning documents.

City of Collinsville FOIA (Freedom of Information Act) Request Form — a general public records request form to request municipal records from the City (submit to the FOIA Officer via mail, fax, or email).

Direct online Public Records Request form submitted to the City Clerk/Custodian of Records. Explicitly intended for obtaining city documents (ordinances, meeting minutes, resolutions), includes fields to describe records sought, and lists email/in‑person submission options and fee info — the most straightforward method to request historical zoning ordinances and archives.

Official City of Maplewood public records information page that explains the open records process, contact details, policies, and (typically) links or directions to the actual request form. Useful for background, procedures, and departmental contacts but less direct than the online submission form itself.

Official GovQA public information request portal used by the City Secretary for Texas Public Information Act / open records requests. Direct, city-hosted system likely to be the primary method to request city records (including planning/zoning files and historical ordinances), making it the most straightforward/effective option.

JustFOIA portal configured for the City of Dripping Springs. A good alternative that supports submitting requests, tracking status, and searching request archives — useful for finding prior requests or related historical records, but secondary to the city's primary GovQA portal.

Official City of Erlanger public portal (Kentucky AG/JustFOIA) for submitting a new records request. Direct, easy-to-use entry point intended for general public records — ideal for requesting historical zoning ordinances and archives.

Specific City of Erlanger Public Records Request form hosted on the JustFOIA portal. A good alternative (explicitly for non-police/fire municipal records such as planning/zoning); slightly less general than the portal landing page but equally valid for historical zoning requests.

Direct online public records request form (FormBuilder) with fields for requester name, contact info, date, description of records requested, reason, and captcha. Best option for easily and directly submitting a request for historical zoning ordinances and archives.

Clerk-Treasurer 'Public Access Laws' page that provides legal guidance and contact information for records requests. Useful for understanding process and rights but less direct than the FormBuilder page for actually submitting a request.

City of Bloomington public records/FOIA portal (JustFOIA) for submitting new records requests and tracking responses — a general municipal records request form usable to request planning/zoning documents.

Official Borough of Bogota OPRA PDF form — direct, official public records request form intended for municipal records. Best choice for requesting historical zoning ordinances/archives because it is the municipality's own form, clearly framed for OPRA requests, and can be submitted by the recognized custodian of records.

Third‑party online OPRAMachine portal — convenient web-based submission and tracking for OPRA requests. Useful as an alternative (easy to use, timestamps requests), but less direct than the official borough form since it routes through a third party and may require follow-up with the municipal records custodian.

Dedicated JustFOIA public records portal for the Town of Surfside. Purpose-built for submitting, tracking, and managing public records requests (selectable recipients such as the Town Clerk). Best choice for requesting historical zoning ordinances and archives because it is direct, structured, and likely to support attachments/status updates.

General Public Records Request form linked from Contact Us, but this URL appears to point to a Sitefinity admin/edit page (may be inaccessible or not a user-facing form). If a functioning public request form is available via the town Contact Us page it can be used as an alternative, but it is less direct and may be harder to use/track than the dedicated FOIA portal.

City Clerk's online Public Records Request page — best option because it provides an online submission method, links to a printable PDF, and a Laserfiche public records portal. Easier to submit, track, and includes direct access to ordinance/agenda/resolution categories useful for historical zoning records.

Printable general Public Records Request form (PDF). Fully usable for requesting planning/zoning records and historical ordinances but less convenient than the online/Laserfiche portal since it requires printing/emailing/mailing or scanning for submission.

City of Harlingen's online Public Records Request portal — direct, city-specific submission under the Texas Public Information Act, likely the easiest way to request historical zoning ordinances and archived zoning records and to track the request.

Texas Attorney General public information request form — an official, general-form template usable for requests to any Texas public body. Good alternative if you prefer a standard AG form or if the city portal is unavailable, but less direct/convenient than the city's online portal.

Digital FOIA/public records submission form covering all departments except Police. Easiest to use (online), likely fastest processing and best for submitting and tracking a request for historical zoning ordinances and archives.

General Village FOIA fillable PDF that covers municipal records (use of the form not required). Official and comprehensive; good alternative if you prefer a downloadable/printable form or need to attach supporting documents.

FOIA fillable PDF targeted to Administration/Finance. Can be used for planning/zoning records but is narrower in scope than the general Village form and less convenient than the online form — useful if you know the records are held by Admin/Finance or need a department‑specific submission.
City-wide Request for Open Records form (PDF) to request public records from the City of Bardstown; includes submission instructions (drop off, mail, or email to openrecords@bardstownconnect.com).

Texas Attorney General's generic Public Information Request form (PDF) for requesting records under the Texas Public Information Act; not specific to Texarkana but can be used to request city/town records (including planning/zoning) from a municipal government.

City Clerk 'Request for Information' online form with explicit fields for records requested, desired format, fees, and requester contact — most direct and complete for asking for historical zoning ordinances and archives.

General Record Request Form linked from the City Clerk page; suitable for obtaining ordinances but appears more generic/simpler than the City Clerk form (may require follow-up for format/fee details).

Best option — an online FOIA/public records request that explicitly lets you specify the department (including Planning), describe the records, choose delivery method, and notes the FOIA fee schedule. Most direct and convenient for requesting historical zoning ordinances or archives.

Good alternative — the FormCenter page (non-www) for the FOIA request. Appears to be the same online request entry point and includes a link to a printable FOIA PDF. Useful if you prefer the site-hosted form or need the printable copy.

Direct PDF of the FOIA request form — perfectly usable and appropriate for requesting records, but less convenient than the interactive online FormCenter version. Good fallback if you prefer to download, print, sign, and submit a paper request.
A general FOIA/public records request form (PDF) for requesting public records from the City of Ward (Arkansas), suitable for obtaining city documents such as ordinances or zoning records.
Link to the City of Sonoma's CivicWeb portal for submitting general public records requests under the California Public Records Act (a citywide records request portal).

City's CivicPlus online Public Records Request (City Clerk) page — provides an online submission interface and also offers the PDF. Best choice because it allows direct electronic submission to the City Clerk, captures required fields (request description, date range, contact info, preferred format) and is explicitly tied to CA Public Records Act requests, making it the easiest and most reliable way to request historical zoning ordinances/archives.

Direct PDF of the City's Public Records Request Form — fully suitable for requesting municipal records (including historical zoning ordinances). Useful if you prefer to download, print or attach to an email, but slightly less convenient than the online CivicPlus submission since it may require manual submission steps (print/mail or email).

Official Abington Township Right-to-Know (Open Records) request form (PDF). This is the most direct and appropriate form for requesting township records such as historical zoning ordinances and archives because it is the township's own RTK form and is tailored for submission to Abington Township.

Pennsylvania Office of Open Records (OOR) online RTKL request form. Good alternative — it includes 'Abington Township (Montgomery County)' in the agency dropdown and allows online submission and tracking. Useful if you prefer an online portal or need a centralized route (or if you later need to involve the OOR for an appeal), but it's less direct than submitting using the township's own form.

Official online Open Records Request form on the city website. Direct, easy to use for Texas Public Information Act requests, lets you describe records and submit electronically — best first option for requesting historical zoning ordinances/archives.

Fillable PDF Open Records Request form. Good alternative when you want an offline/copyable record of your request; explicitly suited for general city records (including planning/zoning). Slightly less convenient than the online submission but useful for documentation and email/print submission.

CivicPlus-hosted copy of the city's Open Records Request form (appears to mirror the official form). Usable for requests but likely redundant with the official granbury.org page; ranked lower because it's a duplicate/alternate host rather than the primary city domain.

Statewide Pennsylvania Right-to-Know Law (RTKL) request PDF — official, generic RTK form accepted by PA municipal agencies. Best and most direct choice for requesting historical zoning ordinances/archives from Township of Reading when a township-specific form is not available.

City of Reading RTK/public records form — a direct municipal form but tailored to the City of Reading, not the Township of Reading. Useful as a template or if the township accepts municipal-style submissions, but less likely to be the correct/accepted form for the township.
Link to the Freedom of Access Act (FOAA) / Information Request Form page for requesting town records (general public records request for the town).
